Title: ‚ÄòSurf's Up': TV Series Adaptation Of Sony Comedy Pic In Works At Atomic Cartoons
Description:
By Jesse Whittock 

International TV Co-Editor


EXCLUSIVE: Ash Brannon and Chris Buck's Academy Award-nominated animated mockumentary feature Surf's Up is set for the small screen treatment.


Thunderbird Entertainment Group's Atomic Cartoons is developing Surf's Up: The Series, an animated show based on the Sony Pictures Animation and Columbia Pictures film from 2007. The comedy series will target kids aged 6-9 with 11-minute episodes.


	Lienne Sawatsky, Dan Williams, and John Hazlett, the trio behind animated children's series' The Guava Juice Show, are writing the adaptation, and will serve as showrunners. Jennifer Twiner McCarron, CEO and Chair of Thunderbird Entertainment, will exec produce alongside Atomic Cartoons' Joel Bradley and Aaron Behl and Sony's Rick Mischel. Kitty Walsh will be co-executive producer for Atomic. 

	











	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	Books
	



	
		
					'Handmaid's Tale' Author Margaret Atwood Mocks Book Ban With New Short Story & Now The Ban's On Hold "Until Further Notice"		
			















	Executives
	



	
		
					Blue Ant Studios' Global Acquisitions Boss Lilla Hurst To Exit After Three Years		
			








	The original Surf's Up starred the likes of Shia LeBeouf, Jeff Bridges, Zooey Deschanel, Jon Heder and and James Woods, and was nominated for an Oscar for Best Animated Feature 18 years ago. It parodied surf documentaries such as Riding Giants, following a teenage northern rockhopper penguin, Cody Maverick, who dreams of becoming a professional surfer by competing in the Big Z Memorial competition on Pen Gu Island.




			Watch on Deadline		







	The series will follow an over-confident teen penguin named Flip, who teams a zany bunch of young surfers in his attempt to become a surf legend. Things go spectacularly wrong and the wipeouts are spectacular, so they instead they build their own surf community on Pen Gu Island. Characters from the movie such as Cody, Big Z and Chicken Joe will return.


	‚ÄúOur team at Atomic is thrilled to be working on Surf's Up: The Series and for the opportunity to introduce these adored characters to the small screen, reaching new and existing fans of the iconic animated film,‚Äù said Twiner McCarron, who is also the CEO of Atomic in addition to Thunderbird.


	‚ÄúLienne, Dan and John are passionate about only two things in life ‚Äì penguins and surfing,‚Äù added Behl. ‚ÄúIt was undeniable that they were the write team ‚Äì pun intended ‚Äì to adapt Surf's Up as a hilarious animated series.‚Äù

	











	Atomic has bases in Vancouver, Ottawa and L.A., and is known for the likes of The Last Kids on Earth, Rocket Saves the Day and Mermicorno: Starfall, which is currently in production. It has also worked on brands such as LEGO, My Little Pony and CoComelon. Atomic's parent, Thunderbird, is behind the likes of Super Team Canada, Molly of Denali, Highway Thru Hell, Kim's Convenience, Boot Camp and Sidelined: The QB and Me, and operates TV sales division Thunderbird Distribution and Thunderbird Brands, which manages consumer products rights.


	The plan is to market Surf's Up: The Series internationally to land TV partners and consumer products lines.


	‚ÄúWe're excited to be partnering with Atomic and their long history of bringing great intellectual property to series animation,‚Äù said Sony's Mischel. ‚ÄúSurf's Up is iconic and we look forward to a whole new audience getting to know these characters.‚Äù

Title: ‚ÄòSpaceballs 2' Starts Production; Anthony Carrigan & George Wyner Join Amazon MGM Studios Sequel
Description:
By Anthony D'Alessandro 

Editorial Director/Box Office Editor


	Amazon MGM Studios has made official what Deadline previously told you: There is a Spaceballs 2 with Rick Moranis, Bill Pullman and Daphne Zuniga reprising their respective roles as Dark Helmet, Lone Star and Princess Vespa. There's also the series additions, which we told you about, including Josh Gad, Keke Palmer and Lewis Pullman.


	New cast members who were unannounced are Barry and Superman actor Anthony Carrigan and A Serious Man‚Äòs George Wyner, who played Colonel Sandurz in the original 1987 movie which grossed over $38M domestic. 


	And of course, the sci-fi comedy pic's architect, Mel Brooks, is back, returning to his roles as Zen Yiddish wise guy Yogurt and President Skroob. 

	










			Watch on Deadline		







	Production is underway with Josh Greenbaum directing. Check out the great cast table read shot above, a nod to what JJ Abrams did when he assembled the Star Wars gang new and old for Force Awakens, more than a decade ago. Expected theatrical release is 2027 for the Spaceballs sequel which is currently untitled. 


	The screenplay logline from scribe duo Benji Samit and Dan Hernandez (Lego Star Wars: Rebuild the Galaxy; TMNT: Mutant Mayhem), and Gad is under wraps. Amazon MGM Studios aren't making official the roles of Palmer, Gad and Lewis Pullman. 


	Imagine Entertainment's Brian Grazer, Ron Howard, and Jeb Brody are producing the film, alongside Brooks, Gad, Greenbaum, and Kevin Salter. Adam Merims, Samit, and Hernandez will executive produce.


	Moranis is represented by Troy Bailey of Bailey Brand Management and Marc Von Arx . Gad is represented by CAA, Range, and Johnson Shapiro. Palmer is represented by 3 Arts and Hertz Lichtenstein. Pullman is represented by CAA and Anonymous Content. Carrigan is represented by United Artists in the U.K., Goodman Genow, and Schlegel Entertainment. Wyner is represented by The House of Representatives. Zuniga is represented by Untitled Entertainment, CESD and Jackoway. Pullman is represented by CAA. Greenbaum is represented by UTA, Entertainment 360, and Lichter Grossman. Benji Samit and Dan Hernandez are represented by 3 Arts, UTA and Jackoway.

Title: Apple TV+'s ‚ÄòThe Hunt' Reveals First-Look Images & Sets Release Date
Description:
By Jesse Whittock 

International TV Co-Editor


Apple TV+‚Äòs French-language thriller series The Hunt has begun its march to launch.


	The series now has a pair of first-look images and a global release date on the streamer: December 3. On that date, two episodes will drop, one then following each week through December 31.


The Hunt, known in France as Traqu√©s (fka A L'Ombre des For√™ts) comes from C√©sar-nominated director C√©dric Anger (Next Time I'll Aim for the Heart), who is creator and director, and stars Beno√Æt Megimel (Pacifiction) and M√©lanie Laurent (Inglorious Basterds). Lupin maker Gaumont is the producer, with Isabelle Degeorges, Cl√©mentine Vaudaux, Alexis Barqueiro and Sidonie Dumas the exec producers.

	











	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	Documentary
	



	
		
					Watch Trailer For 'Stiller & Meara: Nothing Is Lost,' Ben Stiller's Loving Tribute To His Parents: "They Had This Incredible Marriage"		
			















	News
	



	
		
					'The Morning Show' Season 4 Soundtrack: All The Songs You'll Hear		
			








	In the show, Franck (Magimel) and his longtime friends, who spend weekends hunting together, come across another group who begin targeting them for no apparent reason. Despite one of their group being shot, they strike back and manage to escape. However, as Franck goes back to his normal life with wife Krystel (Laurent), he senses he is being watched or tracked by hunters now hell-bent on revenge.




			Watch on Deadline		







	Damien Bonnard, Manuel Guillot, C√©dric Appietto, Angelyna Danabe-Mignot, Paul Beaurepaire, Yann Goven, Sarah Pachoud and Patrick De Vallette also star.


The Hunt will be Apple TV+'s fourth original French-language show after the International Emmy-winning fine wine thriller drama Drops of God, celebrity chef drama Car√™me and high-stakes thriller Liaison starring Vincent Cassel and Eva Green.

Title: Watch Trailer For 'Stiller & Meara: Nothing Is Lost,' From Ben Stiller
Description:
By Matthew Carey 

Documentary Editor, Awards


	In the trailer for his new documentary Stiller & Meara: Nothing Is Lost, Ben Stiller says of his late parents, the comedians Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara, ‚ÄúThey had this incredible marriage.‚Äù


	But it wasn't without its challenges as Stiller explores in the film, which premieres at the New York Film Festival on October 5. They forged the groundbreaking comedy duo Stiller & Meara in the 1960s and ‚Äò70s, but had to balance the demands of career, romantic partnership and parenthood to Ben and his older sister Amy. Eventually, the comedy act split up, but the marriage of Stiller and Meara endured for more than 60 years.

	











	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	News
	



	
		
					'The Morning Show' Season 4 Soundtrack: All The Songs You'll Hear		
			















	News
	



	
		
					Jessica Chastain Says She's "Not Aligned" With Apple On Decision To Postpone 'The Savant'		
			








Stiller & Meara: Nothing is Lost opens in select theaters on October 17 and will begin streaming on Apple TV+ on October 24. Watch the trailer for the film above.




			Watch on Deadline		







	Apple TV+ is home to Severance, the hit drama on which Ben Stiller serves as executive producer, co-showrunner, and director.


	‚ÄúI feel very fortunate to be partnering once again with the incredible team at Apple TV+, this time on a project that is very personal to me and my family,‚Äù Stiller said in a statement. ‚ÄúIt's exciting to finally get to share it with audiences; and a great honor to celebrate my parents, both as I knew them growing up, and as I've come to know them in new ways through the making of this film.‚Äù


	Anne Meara died in 2015 at the age of 85; her husband Jerry Stiller died in 2020 at the age of 92. Following his parents' passing, Ben ‚Äúdug into the vast treasure trove of recordings, footage, letters, and other ephemera with which they documented their personal and professional lives,‚Äù the New York Film Festival writes in its program. ‚ÄúThese extraordinary archives are the foundation of this immensely moving‚Äîand, of course, very funny‚Äîdocumentary, beautifully directed by Stiller and edited by Adam Kurnitz (The Velvet Underground, NYFF59), which charts, with love and candor, the challenges and insecurities that are part of any show-business family's essential makeup.‚Äù

	











	Along with siblings Ben and Amy, the documentary feature's Ben's wife, actress Christine Taylor Stiller, and a Stiller & Meara pal ‚Äì actor Christopher Walken.


	‚ÄúYour father was a kind of a saint,‚Äù Walken tells Stiller in the trailer. ‚ÄúYour mom kind of scared me a little bit. She'd look at me, and I could tell she knows you're up to no good.‚Äù


Stiller & Meara: Nothing Is Lost is produced by Ben Stiller, Academy Award winner John Lesher (Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance), Severance), Emmy Award nominee Geoffrey Richman (Severance, Tiger King) and Lizz Morhaim (The Super Models, Rebuilding Paradise). Executive producers include Academy Award nominee Bryn Mooser (Lifeboat, They Call Me Magic), Emmy Award nominee Justin Lacob (Free Leonard Peltier, The Lionheart) and Emmy Award winner Kathryn Everett (Daughters, Lakota Nation vs. United States), with Emmy Award nominee Matthew Cherchio (Diane Warren: Relentless) serving as supervising producer for XTR. Tony Hsieh and Andy Hsieh also executive produce. 


	Watch the trailer for Stiller & Meara: Nothing Is Lost above.

Title: Emma Watson On "Bone-Breakingly Painful" Lesson About Hollywood
Description:
By Jake Kanter 

International Investigations Editor


Emma Watson has revealed how she struggled to adjust to Hollywood after Harry Potter.


	The British actress has taken a significant step back from acting since 2019's Little Women, and in the past couple of weeks has participated in a couple of interviews about her self-imposed exile. 


	Last week, Watson said she found the process of selling a movie ‚Äúsoul-destroying.‚Äù Now, in an appearance on Jay Shetty's On Purpose podcast (see video below), Watson became emotional recounting her experience of film sets post-Potter.





	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	News
	



	
		
					Emma Watson Says J.K. Rowling's Trans Views Are "Really Painful," But She Never Wants To "Cancel" The 'Harry Potter' Author From Her Life		
			















	News
	



	
		
					Emma Watson Misses Acting, But Not The "Soul-Destroying" Aspect Of The Job		
			








	After playing Hermione Granger for 12 years, she said the J.K. Rowling franchise gave her a warped perspective of the bonds created through filmmaking. 

	










			Watch on Deadline		







	‚ÄúI was coming to those sets with an expectation that I had developed on Harry Potter, which was that the people I worked with were going to be my family, and that we were going to be lifelong friends,‚Äù she explained.


	‚ÄúI came to work looking for friendship. And that was a very painful experience for me, outside of Harry Potter and in Hollywood, bone-breakingly painful, because most people don't come to those environments looking for friendships.‚Äù


	Watson continued: ‚ÄúThey're looking for: ‚ÄòThis is my chance. This is my role. This is what I want out of it. I'm focused. This is my job. This is my career.' I was not of that mindset.‚Äù In a tearful moment, Watson said the shattering of her expectations ‚Äúbroke‚Äù her: ‚ÄúIn a way, I'm proud that it did, because I guess that means I have something left to break.‚Äù

	











	During the same interview, Watson opened up about her rift with Rowling over transgender rights. She told Shetty that Rowling's views were ‚Äúreally painful,‚Äù but she could never cancel the author from her life. ‚ÄúIt's my deepest wish that I hope people who don't agree with my opinion will love me, and I hope I can keep loving people who I don't necessarily share the same opinion with,‚Äù she said.

Title: Former NBC Reality Chief Corie Henson To Lead MrBeast's Studio Division
Description:
By Peter White 

Executive Editor, Television


EXCLUSIVE: Top reality TV executive Corie Henson is taking on a beast of a new role.


	Deadline understands that Henson, who was most recently unscripted chief at NBC, is joining Beast Industries, the company founded by MrBeast, the world's top YouTuber.


	Henson has been named Head of Beast Industry Studios, which oversees MrBeast's YouTube channels as well as its moves into longform streaming series such as Beast Games, the Amazon competition series that has been renewed for two further seasons.


	It comes as MrBeast, otherwise known as Jimmy Donaldson, is expanding more into traditional television alongside his growing YouTube empire, where he has over 440 million subscribers.

	










			Watch on Deadline		







	‚ÄúMrBeast rewired how millions of people consume entertainment. I'm beyond thrilled to join Jimmy and Jeff to help build what comes next,‚Äù Henson said. ‚ÄúWe're not just creating franchises, we're building worlds that actually matter to fans ‚Äî and doing it across every screen.‚Äù


	Henson will report to Jeff Housenbold, CEO of Beast Industries. Tech entrepreneur Housenbold joined the company last year.


	Housenbold told Deadline that he wants to turn Beast Industries into the next Disney. ‚ÄúJust like Disney has Mickey [Mouse], it also has Lucasfilm, Pixar, Marvel, Searchlight, ABC, ESPN, and so on ‚Äî we have Jimmy. We know how to build virality into everything we do, and we're looking to continue building large-scale viewership, whether it's short-form or long-form content, and Corie is going to be integral to getting us there quickly,‚Äù he said.


	‚ÄúCorie brings world-class experience and a proven ability to scale iconic franchises. We're excited for her to lead Beast Industries Studio as we continue to blend the best of traditional entertainment with creator-driven innovation and expand our global impact,‚Äù he added.


	In addition to his YouTube projects and Beast Games, Donaldson is also writing a book with James Patterson, launching an animation studio and a video game platform, and is releasing a theatrical feature. The company is also developing more unscripted and scripted series, which will be overseen by Henson.

	











	Earlier this year, Donaldson explained the rationale behind Beast Games, which saw 1,000 contestants compete in a series of physical, mental and social challenges to win a grand prize.


	‚ÄúI've just always been really excited about taking the big spectacles we do on YouTube but being able to do it over an episodic series where we could actually get to know the contestants and have more depth and story and get more invested into the challenges and games. The idea was to take what we do on YouTube, but make it 10 times bigger and 20 times better,‚Äù he told Deadline.


Beast Games, which premiered on Amazon's streaming service in December and ran through February, saw Donaldson give away $25 million in prize money including a $10M prize to the winner.


	The show was renewed for two more seasons in May.


	Henson has a storied unscripted background. She joined NBCUniversal in 2022, where she became EVP, Unscripted Content, Competition and Game Shows, where she oversaw NBC staples such as America's Got Talent and The Voice as well as Peacock hits The Traitors and Love Island. She left earlier this year as a result of a restructure implemented by Donna Langley.


	Henson's big win at NBC was Deal or No Deal Island, a new spin on the classic game show that returned for a second season after strong ratings for its first season. She also greenlit Destination X, a major new adventure format that is expected to launch later this year and will likely be the first of a number of interesting international co-productions and deals.


	Before NBCU, Henson worked at Warner Bros. Discovery and Fox. She was previously EVP, Head of Unscripted for TBS, TNT and truTV before she decided to leave following Warner Bros.' merger with Discovery. There, she oversaw series such as the reboot of Wipeout, The Go-Big Show and The Cube as well as Harry Potter: Hogwarts Tournament of Houses, the Warner Bros-produced, Helen Mirren-fronted competition series that performed well for TBS and Cartoon Network.


	Before Turner, Henson was EVP, Alternative Entertainment at Fox and before that was EVP, Unscripted Television at Electus and VP, Alternative Series at ABC Entertainment.

Title: South Park kicks the literal shit out of FCC chair Brendan Carr
Description:
Anyone worried that South Park might be feeling a little cowed after the events of the last two weeks may now pretty safely put those fears to rest: Although the Comedy Central show‚Äîwhich missed its deadline last week, as it races through a hyper-political 27th season‚Äîdidn't touch on the death of Charlie Kirk with its latest episode, it went hard on a man who's been very vocal about how other people have talked about it: FCC chair Brendan Carr. Pretty literally, as Trey Parker and Matt Stone took very obvious glee at having the show's version of Carr be brutalized in a number of ways throughout Wednesday night's ‚ÄúConflict Of Interest,‚Äù ending with him stuck in traction in the hospital (with his arm locked in a distinctive pose), while being told that ‚ÄúHe may lose his freedom of speech‚Äù if a virus caught from exposure to cat feces reaches his brain.

To be fair, Carr campaigned just as hard to be South Park‚Äòs latest administration whipping boy, after a week of throwing his weight around to try to get the broadcast TV networks to toe the line and stop saying mean things about his boss. We've noted that Parker and Stone have spent the last few months basically daring administration officials to respond to them this season, and this might be the most aggressive provocation yet, as they depicted Carr being poisoned, pushed down stairs, and covered in cat shit as part of a comedy of errors involving Trump trying to get rid of his unborn child inside Satan's butt. In case the previous sentence didn't make it clear, South Park isn't all that interested in doing nuanced satire right now‚Äîalthough the show did take some more thoughtful pokes at the ever-increasing prevalence of online betting in American culture‚Äîbut it remains shocking and bracing to see how far the series will go when it's on the offensive.

All that and the show weighed in on the Israel-Gaza conflict, tapping Kyle's mom‚Äîwho, like most of the show's adults, can veer wildly in how villainously she acts‚Äîto pointedly note that the current fight in the region is ‚Äúnot Jews vs. Palestine, it's Israel vs. Palestine.‚Äù From there, she traveled to Israel personally to have it out with Benjamin Netanyahu, asking him, ‚ÄúJust who do you think you are, killing thousands and flattening neighborhoods, then wrapping yourself in Judaism like it's some shield from criticism?‚Äù So, yeah: That week off has definitely not mellowed South Park out.

Title: Disney shareholders are demanding answers about ABC's Kimmel suspension
Description:
Sure, being a massive conglomerate capable of buying and selling some of the biggest entertainment brands on the planet sounds fun. You can throw around billions of dollars, engage in all sorts of fun mergers and acquisitions, and only occasionally find yourself forced to kneel and shell out cash in the face of the government being kind of mean to you. But have you considered how many people also wind up yelling at you, even when you only fold in the face of censorship a little bit?

These questions brought to us by news that some of Disney's shareholder groups would like the corporation to answer their questions about its conduct over the last week, and specifically as applies to the nearly week-long suspension of Jimmy Kimmel Live! from the airwaves. Specifically, THR reports that Reporters Without Borders and the American Federation Of Teachers (both of whom own Disney stock, apparently) have issued a letter to the company's board, stating that they believe that there's a ‚Äúcredible basis to suspect‚Äù that the board broke its duty to investors by putting its focus on ‚Äúimproper political and affiliate considerations‚Äù in the Kimmel matter.

Basically, the letter asserts, by bowing to FCC pressure‚Äîindirectly applied to the House O' Mouse after FCC chair Brendan Carr told affiliates that there was ‚Äúan easy way or a hard way‚Äù to deal with Kimmel's comments about right-wing conduct in the wake of Charlie Kirk's murder‚ÄîDisney cost its shareholders a bunch of money in the form of lost public reputation, streaming service cancellations, and drops in stock price. (It's worth noting, in the interest of accuracy, that while Disney's stock price did drop after the Kimmel suspension was announced, it didn't drop much, in the grand scheme of things; that being said, it's not clear yet how many people actually canceled their Disney+ subscriptions, or how much overall damage Disney has done to its rep over the last seven days.) The shareholders are demanding to be given access to board communications about the decision to suspend Kimmel, as well as any back-and-forth between Disney and Nexstar or Sinclair, the affiliate ownership groups that are continuing to keep the talk show off the air in the markets where they own ABC stations.

Reading between the lines, it's easy to see how the shareholder groups are trying to send a message, i.e., that capitulating to the Trump administration's demands could potentially be just as much a hassle for Bob Iger and his fellow members of Disney leadership as trying to fight them. ‚ÄúThe fallout from suspending Jimmy Kimmel Live! sparked criticism as an attack on free speech,‚Äù the letter states, ‚ÄúTriggered boycotts and union support for Mr. Kimmel, and caused Disney's stock to plummet amid fears of brand damage and concerns that Disney was complicit in succumbing to the government overreach and media censorship.‚Äù

Title: Emma Watson talks J.K. Rowling rift, says she's sad a conversation was "never made possible"
Description:
The Harry Potter cast battle lines got drawn pretty quickly once J.K. Rowling started getting seriously into transphobic rhetoric circa mid-2000, divided between those franchise actors, like Ralph Fiennes, who voiced support for the series creator as she got ever-more-vocal about attacking trans rights and identity, and those who dared dissent. Notably, the latter camp included the series' three stars, Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, and Emma Watson, who all expressed their vocal support for trans folk early and often.

Rowling did not take this well, to put it lightly, making public comments suggesting she would never forgive the young performers for their statements‚Äîpretty much all of which started and stopped with quotes like Watson's ‚ÄúTrans people are who they say they are and deserve to live their lives without being constantly questioned‚Äù‚Äîand implying on social media that their presence in the Harry Potter film franchise ‚Äúruins‚Äù those movies for her.

Watson has now addressed the rift, with Variety reporting that the performer, who's been on hiatus from acting since appearing in Little Women back in 2019, popped up on a podcast this week in which Rowling's comments were addressed. Appearing on On Purpose With Jay Shetty, Watson expressed her sadness at the idea of Rowling‚Äîwho she has, obviously, known since she was 11‚Äîcompletely shutting the door on any possible conversations:

I really don't believe that by having had that experience and holding the love and support and views that I have, mean that I can't and don't treasure Jo and the person that I had personal experiences with. I will never believe that one negates the other and that my experience of that person, I don't get to keep and cherish. To come back to our earlier thing‚ÄîI just don't think these things are either or. I think it's my deepest wish that I hope people who don't agree with my opinion will love me, and I hope I can keep loving people who I don't necessarily share the same opinion with. I think the thing I'm most upset about is that a conversation was never made possible.‚Äù

Rowling has, of course, stayed very busy in the years since she and the Potter kids broke up: She's been very publicly funneling parts of her vast wealth into supporting legal challenges to trans rights in the U.K., while also lending her name and support to the new Harry Potter TV series in the works at HBO.

Title: Samurai sequel Ghost Of Y≈çtei is a big, beautiful bowl of gaming gruel
Description:
I haven't run the exact numbers, but I'm pretty sure I must have watched, read, or played at least a hundred different stories about revenge over the course of my life‚Äîdespite the actual opportunities for vengeance cropping up in that same period being, basically, nil. Am I living my life wrong, that the chance to dig two graves (one for my target, and one for the giant pile of clich√©s I'll have to cut my way through to get to them) just doesn't come up in my day-to-day? Am I not swearing enough oaths? The people in Ghost Of Y≈çtei can't seem to go five minutes without swearing a blood-soaked oath about something. It's one of about a dozen things that makes the samurai video game sequel one of the most aggressively dull games I've played in recent memory.

Like its predecessor, 2020's Ghost Of Tsushima, Y≈çtei puts its best foot immediately forward: Studio Sucker Punch Entertainment has made a very pretty video game here, depicting the wide, rolling plains and epic vistas of Northern Japan with meticulous and cinematic detail. From the mountain that lends the game its title‚Äîand dominates its skyline‚Äîto the vast fields of wildflowers you go racing through on horseback on your way to your next avengin', Y≈çtei is undeniably gorgeous, as good a technical pitch as anyone's ever crafted for the PlayStation 5 hardware. No game has ever been more readily and clearly made for the existence of its own Photo Mode‚Äîand if you sense some contempt in that sentence, well, yeah, absolutely.

I admittedly gushed about Tsushima's visuals back in my 2020 review, using the word ‚Äúbeautiful‚Äù fully six times in the body of my write-up. (To let my past self off the hook a bit, we were three months into the pandemic lockdowns, and anything that wasn't the walls of my living room or the inside of my own eyelids was feeling pretty goddamn lustrous by that point.) But the elegance of Tsushima's landscapes also felt genuinely novel at the time, an escalation in what a video game world could look like. Meanwhile, five years of new hardware (and other developers playing catch-up) have only revealed how quickly this kind of visual spectacle can start to feel rote. Yes, Y≈çtei is pretty‚Äîbut it's pretty in a way where you can slurp up all of that beauty simply by watching its trailer a couple of times. You see it, register ‚ÄúPretty!‚Äù in your head, and then feel nothing beyond it; none of the game's aesthetic flourishes feel like they're in service of anything meaningful, beyond filling out a roll of eye-catching PR screenshots, and the actual effect often comes off as busy, more than jaw-dropping.



All of that panoramic showing off feels decidedly disconnected, for instance, from the game's plot, which drops you into the boots of hardened vengeance seeker Atsu (Erika Ishii, at least in the game's English voice track). As quickly sketched in Y≈çtei's opening minutes‚Äîand then fleshed out with early flashbacks that mark one of the game's rare narrative high points‚ÄîAtsu gets her motivations straight out of The Big Book Of Plots You've Seen A Million Times Already: Happy childhood, murdered family, list of mask-themed murder targets who've each conveniently migrated to one corner of the game's massive, icon-strewn map. When not distracted by the nine million chores waiting to intrude on her quest for solitary vengeance, Atsu masters new weapons, pursues her targets, and serves as the subject of god only knows how many lectures about the pointlessness of sanguine revenge.

I will note, for the sake of transparency, that I have not finished Ghost Of Y≈çtei, with this review representing 20 hours of dedicated play. It is certainly possible that the game's later sections contain at least one narrative moment that I had not already seen in any five other movies or games you might care to name on this topic; if so, I'd suggest Sucker Punch move that moment forward, so as to make their game's first-through-twentieth impressions a little less dire. As is, Ishii gives a low-key but winning performance as Atsu, but the dialogue is so flat, and the stories being told so rife with samurai film clich√©s, that I found myself actively heckling the writing as I made my way through beat after tired beat. Even when the game tries to make a plot moment zig or zag‚Äîwould you believe, dear reader, that the bad guys have internal lives and motivations that lend shading to the cartoonish cruelty with which they orphaned our heroine?‚Äîthe overall tone is so relentlessly dour that you can predict every single emotional pivot of every single character's arc with only the barest understanding of how these kinds of stories usually go.

This basic unwillingness to present players with anything they haven't seen before extends equally to the game's play. Combat is presented with exciting trappings, with enemies hitting hard enough (and in big enough groups) to frequently put Atsu on her back foot, forcing you to burn resources to heal. But after a few hours (and a few upgrades), the game's fights essentially solve themselves, as you learn to spam parry/block for everything except the handful of enemy moves immune to it, while switching between Atsu's growing arsenal of weapons in order to counter different foe loadouts. (Each new weapon involves studying under a different master, allowing Y≈çtei to add training tropes to its gigantic grabbag of clich√©s.) Big climactic fights can be exciting, as the game's intimidating boss enemies run Atsu through her paces. But by that 20th hour, I was starting to take hits in mook fights not due to difficulty, but because I was getting so bored of the fighting that my attention would flag‚Äîa death knell for a game where the thrills of combat are among its biggest ostensible selling points.

Y≈çtei is somehow even less innovative, meanwhile, in its exploration gameplay, as Atsu takes time out from her critical race towards vengeance to paint pictures, hunt bounties, climb mountains, cook food, pray at shrines, gobble up hundreds of pieces of crafting litter, and befriend the wildlife of Hokkaido. No one instance of this stuff is offensive, and a few of the mission types, like a series of map objectives that see you rescue hunted wolves to empower Atsu's occasional animal companion, can round out to being pretty exciting. 

But just as equally, no one instance of them is something you haven't done in a game of this type before, whether it's summoning your Magically Teleporting Horse to come running up from behind you, or climbing carefully color-coded rocks, or poking around at the Dual Shock 5's touch pad to do little extra bits of interactivity like lighting fires or cooking fish. And none of it will ever leave you alone. Repeating Tsushima's one truly great map game trick‚Äîthe blowing wind that guides the player to their chosen objectives‚Äîto massively diminishing returns, Y≈çtei constantly reminds you that there's more crap to pick up just over that next beautifully realized hill. With collectibles glinting in the sunlight, navigation-aiding birds and foxes suddenly swooping into frame, and the air itself pushing you toward yet another completion point, the game sometimes feels like reality itself is screaming at you to do more, get more, play more. No individual reward (beyond the initial slate of skill points that gets Atsu's basic combat powers online) feels terribly meaningful, but the game's Skinner box side has been carefully calibrated to keep you moving toward the next thing on the horizon, basically forever.

Some of the gameplay elements that Ghost Of Y≈çtei so aggressively replicates are fun, pretty much by default. Sneaking around an enemy camp and slowly merking every single guy inside it, for instance, is always going to carry a thrill, even when developers choose not to do much new with the template. (With the exception of the ability to sometimes call in your wolf pal to help you, stealth combat is pretty much unchanged from Tsushima: Sneak, stab, get caught, giant fight, repeat.) Everything presented here, with the exception of the word-to-word writing, is baseline competent, and frequently fun in small doses. As a way to turn hours of human life into a vague sense of accomplishment, the game ticks all the necessary boxes.

But, god, there's something spiritually draining about seeing this much effort, and this many resources, thrown at a game that doesn't seem to have a single creative idea running through its pretty, massive head. It's not just that Ghost Of Y≈çtei has nothing new to say about revenge. (Like I said up top, pretty much no vengeance-minded story seems capable of cracking that one.) But it also has nothing new to say about sword combat in video games. Or open-world map design. Or crafting systems. Or sibling relationships. Or melancholy. Or how climbing should work in games that sure have a lot of it, while paradoxically not seeming to give two shits about how it feels. It feints at some of these things, some of the time. It throws dozens of upgrades, cosmetic changes, and other little customization elements at you, constantly, to create an illusion of choice. It pours enormous amounts of time and energy into creating the tone and texture of the samurai movies its creators are so clearly obsessed with.

But none of it arrives with any genuine impact, because genuine impact would get in the way of easing the player toward the next simple set of tasks, to keeping them hooked on the ride. The fact is, you've played this game before. You'll almost certainly wind up playing it again. It'll pass through you like water‚Äîor maybe a gorgeously decorated bowl of gruel‚Äîand that's both Ghost Of Y≈çtei's blessing, and its curse.

Title: Marc Maron releases clip slamming star-studded Riyadh Comedy Festival
Description:
This Friday marks the kick-off of the first Riyadh Comedy Festival, a pretty concerted effort by the government of Saudi Arabia to rebrand the capital city as an international comedy destination. To that end, organizers from the Saudi General Entertainment Authority have reportedly thrown around quite a bit of cash to bring in some of the biggest names in the comedy world to perform at the festival, including Dave Chappelle, Kevin Hart, Bill Burr, Aziz Ansari, Gabriel Iglesias, Louis CK, and several more. It has also, correspondingly, brought some critique: Most notably from comedian Marc Maron, who posted a stand-up clip to his social media this week blasting comics for signing on for a festival being put on by a government with a pretty lengthy list of human rights abuses detailed by Amnesty International.

In the clip (posted to the WTF comics' Facebook page), Maron opens by asking his audience ‚ÄúHow do you even promote that?‚Äù Referencing both 9/11 and the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, Maron pulled no punches: ‚ÄúBut don't let that stop the yuks, it's gonna be a good time.‚Äù (True to form, Maron also did a bit of self-deprecation, noting that he wasn't personally invited to the festival: ‚ÄúEasy to maintain your integrity when no one's offering to buy it out.‚Äù)

Maron isn't the only comic who's spoken out about the Riyadh Festival: Shane Gillis has made comments on various podcast appearances, stating that he turned down a reportedly large amount of money to perform at the fest due to his discomfort with Saudi politics. Comedian Tim Dillon was also reportedly fired from the festival this week, allegedly over jokes he made about his decision to sign on for it in the first place, claiming at the time ‚ÄúThey're paying enough money to look the other way.‚Äù (He also joked, ‚ÄúGet over it, so what they have slaves,‚Äù referencing a long litany of allegations of forced labor imposed on migrant workers in the country.) Dillon said on a more recent episode of his show that his management told him ‚ÄúThey heard what you said about them having slaves. They didn't like that.‚Äù Dillon said on the earlier podcast that he was being paid $375,000 for the single show, and that some comics were getting more than a million, it's worth noting that those numbers haven't been confirmed by any other sources.

Title: Annihilation approaches the U.S. in A House Of Dynamite trailer
Description:
Last year, Oppenheimer took home best picture for its depiction of the genesis of the United States' nuclear program. This year, Kathryn Bigelow's A House Of Dynamite imagines its end. ‚ÄúI always thought just being ready is the point,‚Äù Idris Elba's character says in the film's new trailer. ‚ÄúIt keeps people in check, keeps the world straight. If they see how prepared we are, no one starts a nuclear war.‚Äù As you can probably imagine, that's not what happens.

The rest of the trailer watches as a group of high-level government officials‚Äîincluding characters played by Rebecca Ferguson and Jason Clarke‚Äîpanic and scramble as an intercontinental ballistic missile heads straight for the continental United States. At one point, someone remarks that they've never seen the military readiness condition set to DEFCON 2 (near nuclear war) before. Later, Gabriel Basso's character remarks that diverting the missile is like ‚Äúhitting a bullet with a bullet.‚Äù The situation is very grim. 



‚ÄúThese are dedicated professionals at the highest level of government being called on to make impossible decisions in the most extreme circumstances imaginable, which is almost scarier in a way,‚Äù Bigelow‚Äîwho said she sees this film as part of an unofficial triptych including The Hurt Locker and Zero Dark Thirty‚Äîtold Tudum. ‚ÄúI wanted the view of the film to be trained inward, not outward, and for the audience to lean into the ambiguity at the heart of the nuclear debate: How can we call this defense when the outcome could well be total destruction? The antagonist is the system we've built to essentially end the world on a hair trigger.‚Äù

A House Of Dynamite premieres in select theaters on October 10, before streaming on Netflix October 24.

Title: ‚ÄòStar Trek' Legend Rushed To Hospital After Suffering Medical Emergency
Description:
‚ÄúStar Trek‚Äù actor William Shatner, who played the role of Captain Kirk, was rushed to the hospital on Wednesday, Sept. 24, TMZ reports. He is 94 years old.

The outlet adds that he ‚Äúexperienced an issue with his blood sugar while at his home in Los Angeles late Wednesday afternoon,‚Äù with the actor having ‚Äúcalled emergency medical service workers for help as a precaution and paramedics showed up in an LAFD ambulance.‚Äù

Shatner was taken to a local hospital, with TMZ reporting that he's doing ‚Äúgood‚Äù and ‚Äúresting comfortably.‚Äù

TMZ posted on social media, sharing the news, and many fans left comments, showing support for Shatner. 

‚ÄúüôèüèΩüôèüèΩüôèüèΩ,‚Äù one fan commented.  

‚ÄúOh no.. I hope he's not beamed up just yet.. Stay strong @WilliamShatner.. Engines need more Warp Speed,‚Äù someone wrote. 

‚ÄúWishing Captain Kirk well,‚Äù a fan said.

In June 2025, Shatner opened up about a medical condition he has been dealing with for years called tinnitus.

According to the Mayo Clinic, tinnitus is ‚Äúwhen you experience ringing or other noises in one or both of your ears,‚Äù however, it isn't ‚Äúcaused by an external sound, and other people usually can't hear it.‚Äù The condition began when he was filming ‚ÄúStar Trek‚Äù due to the special effects explosion.

In the video released by the nonprofit organization Tinnitus Quest, Shatner aimed to spread awareness.

‚ÄúOver the years, I've had many ups and downs with my tinnitus,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI know from firsthand experience just how difficult it can get.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äùs a diverse condition that comes in different degrees of severity. About 1‚Äì2% of the population suffer from a chronic, debilitating form of tinnitus. There are no effective treatments‚Äîand that's why we need more research,‚Äù he added. 

A post shared by William Shatner (@williamshatner)

On Aug. 7, William Shatner took to Instagram, revealing to fans that, at the age of 94, he has decided to release a book. 

‚ÄúMy dear followers, I wanted to drop a bit of a teaser: I'm writing a new book. Even Better: the book's all about YOU, the fans, and you can be a part of it, maybe even be in it!,‚Äù he captioned the post. ‚ÄúGo to WilliamShatnerAndYou.com to find out more!‚Äù

Shatner has played many iconic roles, including Captain Kirk, Denny Crane, T.J. Hooker. So with that, he is asking fans to ‚Äúsubmit your own tale of how my characters: be it Kirk, T.J. Hooker, or even Denny Crane‚Äîhave touched your life.‚Äù And a lucky few will get the opportunity to be interviewed by Shatner about their stories, while will be featured in the book.

Title: Keanu Reeves' Girlfriend Responds to Wedding Rumors With Romantic Photo
Description:
Alexandra Grant set the record straight about her relationship with Keanu Reeves. The 52-year-old artist took to Instagram on September 24 to shut down wedding rumors, sharing a candid photo of herself kissing the 61-year-old actor at Roden Crater in Flagstaff, Arizona.

A post shared by Keanu Reeves (@keanureeves.media)

‚ÄúThis is a real photo. Not an engagement photo or an AI wedding announcement‚Ä¶ simply a kiss!‚Äù she wrote in her caption. ‚ÄúWe're at Roden Crater, and Keanu and Gard had just finished interviewing James Turrell for Visionaries.‚Äù

Grant called the headlines ‚Äúfake news‚Äù and confirmed she and Reeves never tied the knot. ‚ÄúI'm sharing it here to say thank you to everyone for the congratulations on our wedding. Except we didn't get married,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúGood news is much needed these days, but it's still fake news, so be careful out there! So, here's a bit of real happiness!‚Äù 

Read Alexandra's complete statement here.

A representative for Reeves also addressed the speculation on Sept. 23. ‚ÄúIt is not true,‚Äù the rep told People. ‚ÄúThey are not married.‚Äù The couple first went public in November 2019 when they walked the red carpet together at the LACMA Art + Film Gala in Los Angeles. 

Nearly a decade earlier, they had collaborated on the 2011 book ‚ÄúOde to Happiness.‚Äù 

At the time of their debut, a source told People, ‚ÄúKeanu wants to openly share his life with her. He is extremely happy and grateful to have Alex in his life.‚Äù

The marriage rumors surfaced just as Reeves began his Broadway debut in ‚ÄúWaiting for Godot.‚Äù Grant celebrated the milestone with another heartfelt Instagram post, praising his portrayal of Estragon.

A post shared by Brian Skope (@skopephotography)

‚ÄúTo Keanu ‚Äî who is not on social media, and with whom I'll share this later ‚Äî your hard work and dedication to trying something new and brave is so inspiring, artist to artist,‚Äù she wrote. 

‚ÄúYour Estragon is unlike any I've seen before ‚Ä¶ funny, lonely, pensive, philosophical.‚Äù

She also applauded director Jamie Lloyd and the cast, calling the production ‚Äúexciting, wildly imaginative, surprising.‚Äù

A post shared by Keanu Reeves (@keanureeves.media)

Reeves and Grant first met in 2009 at a dinner party and went on to collaborate on the books ‚ÄúOde to Happiness‚Äù and ‚ÄúShadows.‚Äù In 2017, they co-founded X Artists' Books, with their friendship eventually blossoming into romance.

Though protective of their privacy, the pair have shared glimpses of their love over the years. At the 2023 MOCA Gala in Los Angeles, they kissed on the red carpet, and Reeves later told People that his happiest recent moment was with Grant: ‚ÄúA couple of days ago with my honey. We were in bed. We were connected. We were smiling and laughing and giggling. Feeling great. It was just really nice to be together.‚Äù

From blockbuster hits like ‚ÄúThe Matrix,‚Äù ‚ÄúJohn Wick,‚Äù and ‚ÄúSpeed‚Äù to his latest chapter on Broadway, Reeves continues to thrive as an actor. Yet some of his most meaningful moments are found offscreen, in the life and love he shares with Grant.

Title: Jennifer Aniston Reacts to Pal Jimmy Kimmel's On-Air Return
Description:
Jennifer Aniston is showing Jimmy Kimmel love after the Tuesday, September 23 return of his show ‚ÄúJimmy Kimmel Live!‚Äù The ‚ÄúFriends‚Äù star took to her Instagram Stories to share a repost of a shot from the late night host's account that shows him walking underneath a lit up ‚ÄúOn Air‚Äù sign. Aniston captioned the post with a simple heart emoji to show her support.

The actress has been a guest on ‚ÄúKimmel‚Äù multiple times, and Parade says she has also been ‚Äúgood friends for more than a decade‚Äù with the comedian. After the show's suspension on Wednesday, September 17, Aniston joined over 400 other celebrities to sign an open letter sticking up for Kimmel and championing free speech on television.

Ahead of Kimmel's big comeback, he and his longtime sidekick, Guillermo Rodriguez, comically pretended to have planned a totally different opener as they appeared dressed in banana and monkey costumes. ‚ÄúMaybe we should change?‚Äù they playfully joked after viewing news clips calling the moment ‚Äúthe most anticipated monologue in late night.‚Äù

Kimmel received a standing ovation as he walked onto the stage. He talked about the importance of being able to share his opinions, saying, ‚ÄúThis show is not important, but what's important is that we get to live in a country that allows us to have a show like this,‚Äù he told fans. He then referenced talk show hosts from other places he says have told him they would get ‚Äúthrown in prison‚Äù for making fun of those in power. 

‚ÄúOur freedom to speak is what they admire most about this country. And that's something I'm embarrassed to say I took for granted until they pulled my friend Stephen off the air,‚Äù he explained, referencing announcement by CBS that ‚ÄúThe Late Show With Stephen Colbert‚Äù will end in May 2026 when Colbert's contract is up. The New York Times says Colbert's farewell season kicked off in July.

He then called efforts to coerce local affiliates to take his own show off the air ‚Äúun-American.‚Äù One fan commented on YouTube that they still can't view the show on local TV, writing, ‚ÄúI never thought I'd be unable to watch a TV show in this country, but tonight my local ABC station in East Tennessee, owned by Nexstar, is not showing Jimmy Kimmel Live. It's blatant censorship. And outrageous. Good to have you back, Jimmy.‚Äù

When Aniston dropped by Kimmel's show last year, the host introduced her as ‚Äúone of the most loved human beings in all the world,‚Äù after calling her ‚Äúa legendary star of screens big and small.‚Äù The 56-year-old was on to promote her children's book, ‚ÄúClydeo Takes a Bit Out of Life.‚Äù

Aniston brought her rescue dog by the same name along, and talked about a special project she started called The Clydeo Fund. She explained, ‚ÄúI started that because I care about helping animals and the dogs, shelter dogs.‚Äù She said the book if for ‚Äúhelping kids find their passions,‚Äù and lamented that ‚Äúkids today are so distracted by those little telephones.‚Äù

Title: Who Got Eliminated First on ‚ÄòSurvivor' 49
Description:
The ‚ÄúSurvivor‚Äù 49 premiere wasted no time in shaking up the game. In Fiji's sweltering heat, the castaways battled through their first challenge, formed tentative alliances, and marched into their opening Tribal Council‚Äîwhere one player's torch was snuffed, becoming the first to leave the game. With host Jeff Probst guiding the action, ‚ÄúSurvivor‚Äù 49 proved from the very start that every second counts.

During the immunity challenge, all three tribes compete for safety from tonight's tribal council. Only one will be sent to elimination. Hina and Ali win immunity while Kele is sent to tribal council tonight. One of the members of Kele will be going home tonight.

The men of Kele tribe are targeting Nicole. While others are pointing fingers toward Annie. The votes follow suite and the first player voted out at Tribal Council becomes Nicole.

To to be updated with Tribal Council Results.

The season opened with the introduction of three tribes: Kele, Hina, and Uli. The 18 new contestants arrived by boat, each carrying ambition, strategies, and a lifetime of stories. Among them: Kimberly ‚ÄúAnnie‚Äù Davis, a musician-entrepreneur from Austin; Alex Moore, a political communications director from Evanston, Illinois; Nate Moore, a former Marvel Studios executive; and many others with unique backgrounds.

Long before the first torch was extinguished, the premiere revealed a behind-the-scenes shake-up: two original castaways violated pre-game rules and were removed, forcing the producers to bring in two alternates‚ÄîJason Treul and Michelle ‚ÄúMC‚Äù Chukwujekwu‚Äîjust 12 hours before filming. This unprecedented move added extra intrigue to the early dynamics. The alternates entered with fresh eyes and fewer expectations, though not necessarily fewer risks.

Once tribes were settled, producers dropped a punishing marooning challenge: castaways raced to secure essential supplies and establish camp dominance. From there they battled for reward advantages, sowed seeds of trust (and doubt), and jockeyed for position ahead of the first Tribal Council. Tensions simmered in the humidity, and alliances began whispering.

‚ÄúSurvivor‚Äù 49 carries an added layer of anticipation because it serves as the final season before the franchise's landmark 50th installment. Fans and producers alike recognize that the buildup to ‚ÄúSurvivor‚Äù 50 will bring heightened expectations, major twists, and a celebration of the show's legacy. With that in mind, every move in season 49 feels magnified, as players not only fight for the title of Sole Survivor but also set the stage for what promises to be one of the biggest chapters in the series' history. 

Adding to the buzz, two castaways‚ÄîRizo ‚ÄúRiz God‚Äù Velovic and Savannah Louie‚Äîare already confirmed to return for season 50, making their performances this year even more closely watched.

Title: ‚ÄòAmerica's Got Talent' Season 20 Top 10 Finalists
Description:
The final performances take part on ‚ÄúAmerica's Got Talent‚Äù season 20 tonight on NBC. The Top 10 acts have been determined, and the finalists are ready to perform live in the ‚ÄúAGT‚Äù finale tonight. We have the Finals details below for who is performing tonight on ‚ÄúAmerica's Got Talent‚Äù 2025.

The Semifinals took place last week on ‚ÄúAGT‚Äù 2025. America voted, and six acts moved on to the Finals, joining the four Golden Buzzer acts from the Quarterfinals. Now it's time for those 10 acts to perform for America's votes on Tuesday, September 23, at 8/7c on NBC.

For tonight's episode, the 10 finalists will be taking the stage one last time. These 10 acts will all be fighting for America's votes and a chance to be named the winner of ‚ÄúAmerica's Got Talent‚Äù season 20.

Only one act can win it all, but who will it be? Check out the acts performing tonight on ‚ÄúAmerica's Got Talent‚Äù season 20 right here.

Turner is an improv rapper who amazes me every performance. While he seems to doubt he should be in the Finals, America voted, and this guy, I feel, is going to amaze us tonight with what he does.

Sanchez was eliminated before performing in the Semifinals on the first season of ‚ÄúAmerica's Got Talent.‚Äù Now, she is back and ready to perform in the ‚ÄúAGT‚Äù finale for season 20, while also being nine months pregnant. The season 11 runner-up on ‚ÄúAmerican Idol‚Äù is ready to take it all the way for a win.

Jourdan was one of Howie Mandel's Golden Buzzers from the audition rounds. He then got food poisoning during the Quarterfinals, but powered through and has now made it to the Finals.

We all know that choirs usually do well on ‚ÄúAGT,‚Äù so here we are with another choir in the Finals. Simon Cowell definitely seems to be a fan of theirs, which could help them in their fight to win this week.

This act was one of Simon's Golden Buzzer acts during the audition rounds. Everyone was then shocked when Howie didn't give them one in the Quarterfinals. However, they have made it to the ‚ÄúAGT‚Äù finale, and I think they have a real shot at being named the winner.

Mama Duke blew up on TikTok after her audition video went crazy online. She then came out and sang another original song for the Quarterfinals. Mel B loved it and hit the Golden Buzzer for her, sending Mama Duke straight to these Finals.

Another Golden Buzzer act, as Micah Palace impressed Simon during the Quarterfinals, to get him to hit the buzzer for him. Simon felt Micah's original song could be the anthem for the World Cup when it comes to North America.

While there are a lot of singers on ‚ÄúAmerica's Got Talent‚Äù season 20, we do need those danger acts. Sirca Marea provides that, as this aerial act does such dangerous tricks while flying in the air. They added blindfolds for the Semifinals.

It's been a while since we've seen Steve Ray Ladson on ‚ÄúAmerica's Got Talent‚Äù 2025. He performed the first week of the Quarterfinals and got Sofia Vergara to hit the Golden Buzzer for him, sending him to the Finals thanks to his original song.

This dance group wanted to impress Mel B during their Quarterfinal performance since she was confused during their audition. She was impressed, but Howie was impressed even more and hit the Golden Buzzer for them, sending them straight to the Finals.

Catch all of these acts tonight at 8/7c on NBC, as the Finals on ‚ÄúAmerica's Got Talent‚Äù season 20 take place.

Want to know who wins ‚ÄúAGT‚Äù 2025? Find out with our ‚ÄúAGT‚Äù Finale Results Live Recap right here!

Title: Los Angeles Festival of Movies Drops Sponsor MUBI Amid Investor's IDF Ties
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

The Los Angeles Festival of Movies (LAFM), heading into its third year April 9 ‚Äì 12 in 2026, has parted ways with MUBI as a presenting sponsor, as LAFM shared on Instagram Thursday.

The festival launched in 2024 with MUBI as a sponsor to bring the best of independent film to Los Angeles over one weekend. MUBI has been subjected to internal and external strife since receiving a $100 million investment from the venture capital company Sequoia, which has also supported companies tied to Israeli military technology amid the war on Gaza. 

 










MUBI CEO Efe Cakarel said in August that the distributor and streamer's profits have no relationship to other companies in Sequoia's portfolio. MUBI secured the investment at the end of May 2025, around the time it acquired the Jennifer Lawrence-starring film ‚ÄúDie My Love‚Äù out of Cannes for a reported $24 million. MUBI declined to comment on the LAFM news, and referred back to Cakarel's statement from August.

Related Stories Netflix Picks Up Laura Poitras and Mark Obenhaus' Documentary ‚ÄòCover-Up' Tribeca Festival Reveals Dates and Details for 25th Edition in 2026 

Filmmakers and MUBI staff have since implored the company to drop its relationship with Sequoia, with a request to remove Sequoia partner Andrew Reed from MUBI's board. 

 










MUBI's fall slate includes, along with ‚ÄúDie My Love,‚Äù Kelly Reichardt's ‚ÄúThe Mastermind‚Äù and Jim Jarmusch's Venice Golden Lion winner ‚ÄúFather Mother Sister Brother.‚Äù At the Venice Film Festival this year, Jarmusch expressed discontent over MUBI's relationship with Sequoia and said he'd had conversations with its leaders about next steps.

Back in August, IndieWire obtained a letter signed by roughly half of MUBI's staff sharing frustrations over the investment. Cakarel said that Sequoia is a minor investor in the company with no oversight on programming or distribution. Expected on October 15 is an internal policy at MUBI, to be shared publicly, on guidelines to ethical investments.

Micah Gottlieb and Sarah Winshall co-founded the L.A. Festival of Movies as a response to the 2018 discontinuation of the L.A. Film Festival. Gottlieb's film non-profit Mezzanine also serves as a sponsor.

Here's the festival's full statement, as shared on Instagram, below. IndieWire has reached out to MUBI for comment.

In the spirit of continuing to build trust and transparency with our community, we want to share that LAFM has parted ways with our presenting sponsor MUBI, on account of its financial ties to Sequoia Capital, a company invested in Israeli military technology and the ongoing campaign of genocide in Gaza.
 










This was not a decision taken lightly. LAFM is still a brand-new festival run by a fledgling nonprofit organization, and we are still largely dependent on corporate sponsorships and donations. This decision definitively puts us behind on our fundraising goals for next year.

With MUBI, we were able to work with a marketing team that understood our mission of bold curation, and supported us in cultivating dynamic spaces for cutting-edge arthouse and independent cinema. We are now actively seeking sponsors and donors who share those values.

When we began in 2024, we arrived in an incredibly precarious environment for independent cinema. We planted a seed in a city dominated by the commercial film industry, in order to build a foundation for the kind of film culture we want to perpetuate.

Like many, we have been witnessing the genocide in real time on our social media feeds. And like many, we question our material ability to move the needle as a cultural arts organization. But we do not want to remain indifferent.

We are so lucky to proceed with intention, curiosity and warmth. It is these values that we want to imbue to our partners and to our audience.

The support that we get from you goes a long way. 

Please consider supporting us, and help us make it to 2026.

Title: ‚ÄòOne Battle After Another' Is Unique in Paul Thomas Anderson's Filmography ‚Äî and So Are Its Box Office Chances
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

When Paul Thomas Anderson‚Äòs previous film ‚ÄúLicorice Pizza‚Äù was released by MGM and United Artists Releasing in 2021, the narrative surrounding the movie was that it was an example of then-MGM film chiefs Mike De Luca and Pam Abdy spending a premium on an auteur director ‚Äî and one who didn't necessarily have a clear box office track record.

Produced on a budget of $40 million, ‚ÄúLicorice Pizza‚Äù made only $34 million worldwide, including just $17.3 million domestic. For another filmmaker who doesn't have 11 Oscar nominations, that might put a damper on what they could command moving forward. 

 










But for PTA's latest ‚ÄúOne Battle After Another,‚Äù Anderson is now commanding a budget that's not just exponentially higher than any he's worked with ‚Äî a report in Variety had it at $115 million, but IndieWire understands it to actually be $130 million ‚Äî it's also higher than anything he's grossed to date at the box office. Not a coincidence, De Luca and Abdy are back at the helm again, this time at Warner Bros., offering him the keys to the castle. 

 











			Popular on IndieWire		




Related Stories Los Angeles Festival of Movies Drops Sponsor MUBI Amid Investor's IDF Ties Netflix Picks Up Laura Poitras and Mark Obenhaus' Documentary ‚ÄòCover-Up' 

All that was at least the narrative early in the year, when De Luca and Abdy had a few costly flops in a row, namely the ‚ÄúJoker‚Äù sequel, and the duo was staring down the pike of another expensive auteur passion project in Ryan Coogler's ‚ÄúSinners.‚Äù The performance of that film shut people up, and the studio's incredible hot streak that also includes ‚ÄúFinal Destination: Bloodlines,‚Äù ‚ÄúWeapons,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Conjuring: Last Rites,‚Äù and ‚ÄúSuperman‚Äù has given them the benefit of the doubt when it comes to PTA, at least for now. 

But the question is warranted. Anderson's most successful movie in his 10-film career is ‚ÄúThere Will Be Blood,‚Äù the 2007 Best Picture nominee and Best Actor winner, which grossed $76.9 million worldwide according to Comscore, a little more than half of what ‚ÄúOne Battle After Another‚Äù costs. 

For all his other films, only ‚ÄúPhantom Thread‚Äù has crossed the $50 million worldwide mark, and that was just barely at $52.2 million. ‚ÄúMagnolia‚Äù clocks in at No. 3 with $48 million in 1999, ‚ÄúBoogie Nights‚Äù made $43 million in 1997, and ‚ÄúLicorice Pizza's‚Äù $34 million comes in fifth.

The last and only time PTA worked with Warner Bros. Pictures (‚ÄúMagnolia‚Äù and ‚ÄúBoogie Nights‚Äù were New Line Cinema releases, now a division of WB) was PTA's worst-performing film (not including his barely-distributed debut ‚ÄúHard Eight‚Äù), 2014's ‚ÄúInherent Vice,‚Äù which made just $14.8 million worldwide. Coincidentally, ‚ÄúOne Battle After Another‚Äù is ‚Äúinspired‚Äù by another Thomas Pynchon novel rather than a direct adaptation. 

 










What sets ‚ÄúOne Battle After Another‚Äù apart from all of those movies is the scale at which Warner Bros. will release it. Having skipped the festivals (PTA just isn't a fan), Warner Bros. is positioning ‚ÄúOne Battle After Another‚Äù as a commercial property and will give it a wide release. Every Anderson movie to date has received a platform release in an amount of theaters you can only count on one hand (OK, ‚ÄúMagnolia‚Äù got a whopping 7 screens). Comparing opening day results for ‚ÄúOne Battle After Another‚Äù to anything in his repertoire will be apples and oranges. And when those films did expand, the most screens he's ever been given were just shy of 2,000 for ‚ÄúLicorice Pizza.‚Äù ‚ÄúBattle‚Äù should easily surpass that.

It's fitting too because ‚ÄúOne Battle After Another‚Äù is arguably unlike any film Anderson has made, the rare film of his to be set in the 21st century and play like a relentless action movie. The $130 million budget certainly looks like it's all there on the screen in the film's elaborate riot scenes and chase sequences on foot and on wheels. And short of Tom Cruise, Anderson has arguably never had an A-lister on Leonardo DiCaprio's level starring, so his own box office cache shouldn't hurt.

Warner Bros. is also following a playbook that it executed to perfection with ‚ÄúSinners,‚Äù releasing ‚ÄúOne Battle After Another‚Äù on a plethora of film formats and premium offerings and getting Anderson out there to explain the value of it. Suffice it to say, Anderson has never had that IMAX bump either. All of that is a sign Warner Bros. is banking that audiences will feel this movie is one you have to see in a theater.

Title: 'Stiller & Meara: Nothing Is Lost' Trailer: Ben Stiller Doc on Parents
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

For his latest directorial outing, Ben Stiller has tackled the toughest of tough subjects: his own family. ‚ÄúStiller & Meara: Nothing Is Lost‚Äù is, on its surface, a very intimate look at the life and work of Stiller's comedic genius parents Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara, but even in the film‚Äòs first trailer, it's clear that the doc goes beyond that (already quite intriguing!) promise.

In the film, ‚ÄúStiller tells the story of his parents, comedy icons Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara, exploring their impact both on popular culture and at home, where the lines between creativity, family, life and art often blurred. In the process, Stiller turns the camera on himself and his family to examine Jerry and Anne's enormous influence on their lives, and the generational lessons we all can learn from those we love.‚Äù

 











			Popular on IndieWire		




Related Stories ‚ÄòNobody Wants This' Season 2 Trailer: Adam Brody and Kristen Bell Become a ‚ÄòWe' Netflix Picks Up Laura Poitras and Mark Obenhaus' Documentary ‚ÄòCover-Up' 

The AppleTV+ documentary will premiere at the New York Film Festival on October 5, with other screenings to follow throughout the festival's run.

The New York Film Festival's own synopsis provides deeper exploration of the film, noting that ‚Äúafter Anne and Jerry passed away in 2015 and 2020, respectively, Stiller dug into the vast treasure trove of recordings, footage, letters, and other ephemera with which they documented their personal and professional lives. These extraordinary archives are the foundation of this immensely moving ‚Äî and, of course, very funny ‚Äî documentary, beautifully directed by Stiller and edited by Adam Kurnitz, which charts, with love and candor, the challenges and insecurities that are part of any show-business family's essential makeup.‚Äù

 










Stiller himself stars in the film, along with his sister Amy Stiller, his wife Christine Taylor-Stiller, his children Ella and Quinlin Stiller, plus Christopher Walken and Stephen Colbert. The doc is produced by Red Hour Films' Stiller and John Lesher, as well as Geoffrey Richman and Lizz Morhaim, with XTR's Bryn Mooser, Justin Lacob and Kathryn Everett, as well as Tony Hsieh and Andy Hsieh serving as executive producers. 

‚ÄúStiller & Meara: Nothing Is Lost‚Äù will be released in select theaters on Friday, October 17 and will start streaming globally on Apple TV+ on Friday, October 24. Check out the film's first trailer below.

Title: ‚ÄòA House of Dynamite' Trailer: Kathryn Bigelow Pushes the Tension to the Breaking Point in Nuclear Missile Thriller
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Kathryn Bigelow is back with her first movie in eight years, the nuclear missile thriller ‚ÄúA House of Dynamite,‚Äù which premiered to raves at Venice, having already been acquired by Netflix in advance. The trailer for ‚ÄúA House of Dynamite‚Äù is here, and it is gripping. Watch it below.

Senior situation room duty officer Rebecca Ferguson (here doing such a great American accent you'll forget about Ilsa Faust immediately) receives shocking news: An intercontinental ballistic missile has appeared over Asia with a trajectory that appears to take it to a Midwest city in the U.S. And, given how fast ICBMs travel, reaching suborbital altitudes, it'll reach that target in 18 minutes. The entire film that follows plays out by toggling back and forth among myriad different perspectives, including Idris Elba as POTUS, in an ever-growing ensemble during those 18 minutes.

 








Related Stories Los Angeles Festival of Movies Drops Sponsor MUBI Amid Investor's IDF Ties ‚ÄòNobody Wants This' Season 2 Trailer: Adam Brody and Kristen Bell Become a ‚ÄòWe' 

The cast also includes Gabriel Basso, Jared Harris, Tracy Letts, Anthony Ramos, Moses Ingram, and Jonah Hauer-King, with Greta Lee and Jason Clarke. It comes from a script by Noah Oppenheim, the former president of NBC News who also wrote Pablo Larrain's ‚ÄúJackie‚Äù as well as co-created the Robert De Niro-led Netflix series ‚ÄúZero Day,‚Äù about a devastating cyberattack on the U.S.

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






IndieWire Executive Editor Ryan Lattanzio wrote in his review that the ‚Äúhorrifically gripping and hopeless‚Äù film ‚Äúwill ruin your day.‚Äù In the best possible way, as he also gave it an A- score and a Critic's Pick, when reviewing it out of the 2025 Venice Film Festival earlier this month.

‚Äú‚ÄòA House of Dynamite' moves at a whirring gradient with an ever-widening ensemble ‚Äî which includes Greta Lee, Jason Clarke, and Moses Ingram as various cogs ‚Äî that can be challenging to keep track of,‚Äù Lattanzio continued. ‚ÄúThe film essentially takes place entirely within an under-20-minute timeline, showing the same events from a shuffling deck of points of view. Bigelow's grindingly focused direction is peerless here, with her already established as a frank and fearless chronicler of American political ambiguity in films like ‚ÄòThe Hurt Locker' and ‚ÄòZero Dark Thirty,' and with ‚ÄòA House of Dynamite' seemingly completing a trilogy about the collapse of the American dream in war times.‚Äù

‚ÄúHardly mere agitprop due to the stylistic intensity of its filmmaking, this gun-to-your-head engrossing movie ‚Äî with its eardrum-piercing and death-rattling sound design and a score by Volker Bertelmann so oppressive it could swallow you whole ‚Äî also wants to shake you out of your slumber.‚Äù

 










‚ÄúA House of Dynamite‚Äù opens in select U.S. theaters on Friday, October 10 and will stream on Netflix starting on Friday, October 24. Watch the trailer below.

Title: Kiyoshi Kurosawa's ‚ÄòCloud' Streams Soon on Criterion: The Master Explains How It's an Ode to American Action Movies
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

‚ÄúHell is waiting for you. I'll be your nightmare forever,‚Äù Yoshii (Masaki Suda) is told at gunpoint in one of the most thrilling sequences of Kiyoshi Kurosawa‚Äòs career in ‚ÄúCloud.‚Äù

It's a line, though, that could apply across the Japanese filmmaker's work, whether the specters in the machine stalking a post-Y2K digital realm in ‚ÄúPulse‚Äù or the elusive serial killer who seems to operate by hypnosis in ‚ÄúCure,‚Äù one of the very best horror movies ever made.

‚ÄúCloud‚Äù is Kurosawa's first movie to weld his techno anxieties to a Western framework, as his movie about a sociopath-adjacent internet reseller and hoarder culminates in the grandest action set piece yet from the filmmaker. And it turns out, Kurosawa intended ‚ÄúCloud‚Äù as homage to American action thrillers like Sam Peckinpah's ‚ÄúStraw Dogs.‚Äù

 








Related Stories Tribeca Festival Reveals Dates and Details for 25th Edition in 2026 Netflix Picks Up Laura Poitras and Mark Obenhaus' Documentary ‚ÄòCover-Up' 

IndieWire exclusively announces that ‚ÄúCloud,‚Äù which played U.S. theaters over the summer and was Japan's submission for the 2025 Best International Feature Oscar, will begin streaming on the Criterion Channel on Tuesday, October 7. The film will premiere alongside a new interview with Kurosawa, part of Criterion's Meet the Filmmakers series, and IndieWire shares an exclusive clip from that interview in the video above.

 










That same day, ‚ÄúCloud‚Äù will also become available for TVOD rentals on Apple TV, Prime Video, and Fandango at Home. A home-video release will follow next February.

‚ÄúI had the desire to shoot the kind of action scenes often seen in American films. However, I knew that to do something like that for Japanese audiences, I would have to choose a completely different type of character to focus on. Like a yakuza, a police officer, or the Japan Self-Defense Force. I really didn't want to do that. That's why I wanted the protagonist to be an average guy who typically avoids heated confrontation but gets caught up in what could be called a shootout,‚Äù Kurosawa says in the clip. 

‚ÄúA protagonist who has no connection to violence whatsoever, yet ultimately becomes a participant in a kind of carnage. When it comes to such a story, I immediately thought of ‚ÄòStraw Dogs.' It's a gruesome action film ‚Ä¶ with not a single positive thing about it. I don't reference Straw Dogs in every scene, but everyone who sees ‚ÄòCloud' immediately notices the resemblance. Since this is a film where people who have never even held a handgun engage in what you would call action‚Ä¶ and murder each other, I knew from the start it'd never be popcorn entertainment. What would happen if someone who had never considered or experienced such a thing suddenly held something that could kill another person?‚Äù

 










IndieWire's David Ehrlich also raved about ‚ÄúCloud‚Äù circa Venice last year, writing, ‚Äú‚ÄòCloud' updates the filmmaker's signature focus for a modern world that's enmeshed in an infinite (but invisible) network of small cruelties and bitter grievances ‚Äî a network so ubiquitous that even the better angels of our nature might drive us straight into hell. Almost too mundane to care about until it becomes impossible to stop watching for much the same reason, this riveting and highly unusual shoot-em-up finds Kurosawa returning to his roots, only to discover that psychological terror isn't quite as abstract as it used to be.‚Äù

Title: ‚ÄòIn Your Dreams' Trailer: Netflix Animation Follows ‚ÄòKPop Demon Hunters' with a Family Fantasy Adventure
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Netflix Animation has already had a very successful 2025, with ‚ÄúKPop Demon Hunters‚Äù becoming the sleeper hit film of the entire summer and a major cultural phenomenon. Now, the streamer hopes to repeat that success with their major animated release of the fall, ‚ÄúIn Your Dreams.‚Äù The first trailer for the film, a fantasy comedy kids adventure in the vein of '80s films like ‚ÄúLabyrinth‚Äù or ‚ÄúThe Neverending Story,‚Äù shows off the next chapter in the streamer's animated slate.

Directed by former Pixar animator Alex Woo in his feature directorial debut, ‚ÄúIn Your Dreams‚Äù focuses on two young siblings, Stevie (voiced by Jolie Hoang-Rappaport) and Elliot (Elias Janssen), whose parents (voiced by Cristin Milioti and Simu Liu) are experiencing tension in their relationship. As Stevie stresses over the possibility that they will split, she and Elliot discover a strange book telling the story of the fabled Sandman, who can makes a person's deepest wish come true. The book grants them the ability to enter into the dream world, where they venture on a quest to find the Sandman and attempt to save their parents' marriage. Other voice actors in the film include Craig Robinson as Elliot's toy giraffe Baloney Tony, as well as Omid Djalili, Gia Carides, SungWon Cho, and Zachary Noah Piser.  

 











			Popular on IndieWire		




Related Stories Netflix Picks Up Laura Poitras and Mark Obenhaus' Documentary ‚ÄòCover-Up' Tribeca Festival Reveals Dates and Details for 25th Edition in 2026 

The film was produced by Netflix Animation and Woo's company Kuku Studios, making its first feature film after having primarily produced preschool series. Woo co-wrote the film with Erik Benson, who also served as co-director of the film, based on a story he conceived with Stanley Moore, Tim Hahn, and Gregg Taylor. The music for the film was composed by John Debney.

 










Aside from ‚ÄúIn Your Dreams,‚Äù Netflix will also release ‚ÄúThe Twits,‚Äù an animated adaptation of the 1980 children's novel by Roald Dahl, on October 17. Other films being released by the streamer this fall include Kathryn Bigelow's political thriller ‚ÄúA House of Dynamite,‚Äù Guillermo del Toro's adaptation of ‚ÄúFrankenstein,‚Äù and Rian Johnson's new ‚ÄúKnives Out‚Äù film ‚ÄúWake Up Dead Man.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn Your Dreams‚Äù will receive a short theatrical release on Friday, November 7, before releasing on Netflix on Friday, November 14. Watch the full trailer for the film below.
